snippet: Money is cheap for companies with good credit, and they are piling into the corporate bond market. But what is good for borrowers may not be so good for lenders.
abstract: Companies with good credit are piling into the corporate bond market to take advantage of cheap money; while the development is good for borrowers, it may be less so for lenders, particularly investors buying the bonds; interest rates have gone so low that some question whether they can fall any farther; yields on investment-grade corporate bonds hit a record low on March 2, with an important Barclays index falling to 3.266 percent, after ending 2011 at 3.737 percent.
lead_paragraph: Money is cheap for companies with good credit, and they are piling into the corporate bond market. But what is good for borrowers may not be so good for lenders.

headline.seo: Low Rates Entice Companies to Borrow
headline.main: In Bonds, Bull Market for Firms
headline.print_headline: In Bonds, Bull Market For Firms

keywords.value: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
keywords.name: subject
